top_categories.workout_context: WYO 131 rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
At 131 miles, WYO 131 punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at WYO 131 when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
WYO 131’s wyoming mountain and high desert gravel and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Racing WYO 131 isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of WYO 131. Make this intensity feel like home.
WYO 131’s mountain gravel, high desert demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Every session at WYO 131 intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
WYO 131’s 7,500ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what WYO 131’s wyoming mountain and high desert gravel delivers on race day.
At 131 miles, WYO 131 rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.
Low-cadence force work builds the muscular strength for WYO 131’s 7,500ft of climbing — especially the grinding, low-speed ascents.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for WYO 131’s 131 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.altitude: WYO 131 with 7,500ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. High altitude (6000-8000+ feet).
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at WYO 131 requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on wyoming mountain and high desert gravel to build confidence. Expect: mountain gravel, high desert, wyoming wilderness.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on TT Threshold, Durability, and Over Under to prepare you for 131 miles of wyoming mountain and high desert gravel in Lander, Wyoming.
